caption: Task Description
steps: In this task, you will be asked to identify and annotate Drugs and their Adverse Effects within a set of tweets posted to Twitter.
A Tweet is a message containing a piece of text.
A Drug is any substance that causes a change in an organism's physiology or psychology when consumed.

An Adverse Effect is any kind of medical problem or undesired negative effect that happens during treatment with a Drug. This includes injury, allergic reactions, overdoses, withdrawals, undesired symptoms and similar.
We will show you 11 tweets made by Twitter users. Each tweet is not altered in any way and it is reported as posted by its author (usernames are anonymized).
For each tweet, we ask you to read its text and to annotate the mentioned Drugs along with their Adverse Effects.
Note that there are some checks throughout the task, and if you do not perform these correctly you will not be able to terminate and get paid.
The data from this task is being gathered for research purposes. No personally-identifying information is recorded. Participation is entirely voluntary, and you are free to discontinue at any point.

caption: Task Instructions
steps: You will be shown one tweet at the time. You will annotate it by highlighting one or more portions of text. You can do that by selecting the text as you normally would.
If you change your mind you will be able to delete any annotation at any time by clicking on the delete button.

Once you select a portion of text you will be able to annotate it by clicking on the DRUG button or on the ADV.EFFECT button.
Note that the label DRUG includes also medications names and active substances nouns, while the label ADV.EFFECT includes descriptions containing verbs, nouns, pronouns, adjectives, adverbs, idioms, slang and mentions of withdrawals and overdoses.

Use the DRUG button to annotate medication names and active substances nouns (not dosages). Use the ADV.EFFECT button to annotate descriptions of Adverse Effects, including all adjectives, idioms, slang, mentions of withdrawals and overdoses.
Note that the annotation buttons are active only if you highlight a portion of text belonging to the tweet. Make sure that your selection does not include any text outside of the tweet’s text box.

The tweets are presented in no particular order. Simply annotate each tweet after reading it. Don't try to guess or randomly annotate, as there are some cross-checks. You’ll need to use the buttons to annotate at least one DRUG for each tweet, otherwise you will not be able to proceed to the following steps.
Below you can find some examples of valid annotations.
Example 1
@USERNAME Cipro destroyed my entire body, from head to toe. Bedridden since 2009. Be VERY careful.
"Cipro" is annotated as DRUG (it is the name of a medication)
"destroyed my entire body" is annotated as ADV.EFFECT (it is an adverse event description which includes an adjective)
"Bedridden" is annotated as ADV.EFFECT (it is the description of an adverse event)
Example 2
Brb, dying of nicotine withdrawal.
"nicotine" is annotated as DRUG (it is the noun which describes an active substance)
"withdrawal" is annotated as ADV.EFFECT (withdrawals are considered adverse drug events)
Example 3
It feels like my brain is melting. 360mg of vyvanse in 24 hours... not smart danielle. not smart.
"vyvanse" is annotated as DRUG (it is the name of a medication)
"my brain is melting" is annotated as ADV.EFFECT (it is the description of an adverse event)
You need to annotate at least one DRUG to proceed to the next tweet.
